title: Henry M. Mullinnix
text:
Henry Maston Mullinnix (July 4, 1892 – November 24, 1943) was a <a href="United%20States%20Navy">United States Navy</a> <a href="aviator">aviator</a> and <a href="Admiral%20%28United%20States%29">admiral</a> who served in <a href="World%20War%20I">World War I</a> and was killed in action commanding a Navy escort carrier division and task force group in the <a href="Gilbert%20Islands">Gilbert Islands</a> location during <a href="World%20War%20II">World War II</a>. He was <a href="List%20of%20U.S.%20general%20officers%20and%20flag%20officers%20killed%20in%20World%20War%20II">one of five flag officers of the U.S. Navy to die in World War II</a> after <a href="Isaac%20C.%20Kidd">Isaac C. Kidd</a>, <a href="Norman%20Scott%20%28admiral%29">Norman Scott</a>, <a href="Daniel%20J.%20Callaghan">Daniel J. Callaghan</a>, and <a href="Theodore%20E.%20Chandler">Theodore E. Chandler</a>.
Biography.
Mullinnix was born in <a href="Spencer%2C%20Indiana">Spencer, Indiana</a> in 1892. He was president of his senior class at <a href="Attica%2C%20Indiana">Attica</a> High School graduating in 1909. He graduated first in his class from the <a href="United%20States%20Naval%20Academy">United States Naval Academy</a> in 1916. He served in the destroyer , engaged in patrol and escort duty off <a href="Ireland">Ireland</a> during <a href="World%20War%20I">World War I</a>. Following service in and , he completed work in <a href="aeronautical%20engineering">aeronautical engineering</a> at Annapolis and <a href="Massachusetts%20Institute%20of%20Technology">MIT</a>, receiving an M.S. degree in 1923. After flight training at <a href="Naval%20Air%20Station%20Pensacola">Naval Air Station Pensacola</a>, <a href="Florida">Florida</a>, he was designated a <a href="United%20States%20Naval%20Aviator">naval aviator</a> on January 11, 1924. He was one of those mainly responsible for developing the <a href="air-cooled%20engine">air-cooled engine</a> for naval aircraft. Besides various shore duty, he served in , , and commanded , between 1924 and 1941. On November 13, 1942, he was promoted to <a href="Rear%20admiral%20%28United%20States%29">rear admiral</a>.
Mullinnix commanded "Saratoga" from April 1943, until August 22, when he was transferred to duty with a carrier division. On November 24, Rear Admiral Mullinnix was on board his flagship (under the command of Captain <a href="Irving%20Wiltsie">Irving Wiltsie</a>) commanding Carrier Division 24 and Task Group 52.3 (Air Support Group of Northern Attack Force (Makin)-Task Group 52) when the escort carrier/flagship which had just participated in the <a href="Battle%20of%20Makin">Battle of Makin</a> was <a href="torpedo">torpedo</a>ed by a Japanese submarine and sunk off <a href="Butaritari">Makin Island</a>, in the <a href="Gilbert%20Islands%20naval%20order%20of%20battle">Gilbert Islands</a>. Declared dead a year later, he was posthumously awarded the <a href="Legion%20of%20Merit">Legion of Merit</a>: 
For exceptional meritorious conduct...as Commander of a Carrier Air Support Group prior to and during the amphibious invasion of Japanese-held Makin Atoll, Gilbert Islands from November 1 to 24, 1943. Displaying outstanding initiative and superior executive ability, Rear Admiral Mullinnix skillfully conducted anti-submarine and air combat patrols supporting our landing operations on this strongly defended island and, through his brilliant leadership, enabled escort carriers to carry out a well coordinated, aggressive attack against the enemy. Rear Admiral Mullinnix's tireless efforts, meticulous attention to detail and loyal devotion to the accomplishment of an extremely difficult and hazardous mission contributed materially to our subsequent capture of this strategic area.
Namesake.
In 1957, the <a href="destroyer">destroyer</a> was named in his honor.
